What Are Mushroom Gummies? Mushroom gummies are a type of dietary supplement that combines the benefits of mushrooms with the deliciousness of gummy edibles.
These gummies are infused with extracts from various types of mushrooms , such as Reishi, Chaga, and Cordyceps, known for their potential health-promoting properties and varying effects.
Gummies made from mushrooms are a more fun and convenient way to add these all-natural ingredients to one‚Äôs daily routine than traditional supplements and taking medications typically taken as capsules or powders.
Typically, the gummies are made to provide particular health advantages linked to the individual mushroom extracts, like improved energy, stress reduction, immune support, and cognitive function .
How Do Mushroom Gummies Work? Mushroom gummies work by utilizing the properties of mushrooms to deliver possible health advantages in a tasty way.
Extracts from a variety of mushrooms are commonly found in these edibles and may have health benefits.
The active ingredients in these mushrooms are absorbed into the body after consumption, where they may interact with different systems to possibly promote general health .
For instance, Lion‚Äôs Mane is frequently linked to cognitive function, Chaga to antioxidant properties, and Reishi to immune system support.
>>Check the best price for Amanita Mushroom Chocolate Caps at Utoya
Types of Mushrooms Used in Gummies Below, we examine the most common types of mushrooms used in magic mushroom gummies.
Chaga Chaga is a type of mushroom that is frequently used in gummies because of its possible antioxidant properties. It is thought to promote general health and immune system function .
Lion‚Äôs Mane Another common mushroom used in gummies, Lion‚Äôs Mane, is thought to promote brain health and has been linked to possible cognitive benefits .
Reishi Gummies frequently contain Reishi, a well-known mushroom in traditional Chinese medicine, due to its possible calming and stress-relieving effects .
Cordyceps Another popular mushroom used in gummies is cordyceps, which may have energy-boosting effects , making it beneficial to individuals struggling with chronic fatigue.
The Benefits of Magic Mushroom Gummies Magic mushroom gummies are becoming more well-known due to their possible medicinal and health advantages.
These mushroom gummies , which come from natural sources, have a number of benefits that appeal to people looking for non-traditional ways to wellness.
Magic mushroom gummies can potentially improve mental health, which is one of their main advantages.
According to research [1], psilocybin, one of the active ingredients in magic mushrooms, may be able to lessen the symptoms of PTSD, anxiety, and depression .
A number of people have reported having profound experiences and feeling more at ease after ingesting magic mushroom gummies.
Magic mushroom gummies have shown promise in helping individuals overcome addiction [2].
Psilocybin-assisted therapy has been shown in studies to help break the cycle of addiction by addressing the root causes and fostering long-term recovery.
Magic mushroom gummies may have advantages for mental health as well as spiritual and personal development.
At the same time, many consumers report psilocybin in psychedelic mushrooms boosts their energy levels while reducing stress and anxiety [3].
>>Check the best price for Amanita Mushroom Chocolate Caps at Utoya
Side Effects of Mushroom Gummies Even though there are many advantages to taking mushroom gummies, it is crucial to remain responsible.
It is essential to speak with a healthcare professional and make sure that consumption takes place in a secure and encouraging environment.
This leads us to potential adverse effects associated with the consumption of magic mushroom gummies, and these include gastrointestinal discomfort, such as bloating, gas, or stomach upset .
Furthermore, some people may be allergic to specific kinds of mushrooms, which can cause allergic reactions like rash, swelling, or itching.
Furthermore, there is a chance that mushroom gummies will interfere with certain drugs or medical conditions.
Before adding magic mushroom gummies to your daily routine, it is crucial to speak with a healthcare provider, particularly if you are expecting, nursing, taking medication, or have any underlying health issues.
How to Choose the Right Mushroom Gummy for You Now that you know magic mushrooms and their specific benefits, examine the following factors before you hop on your shopping adventure.
Picking Your Potency When choosing a mushroom gummy, consider the potency that aligns with your needs.
Whether you are a beginner or an experienced user, selecting the right potency level is essential for achieving the desired effects.
Flavors: Taste the Adventure Examine the range of flavors and decide which suits your taste buds. The taste of amanita mushrooms in the gummy form can range greatly from fruity to earthy tones .
Discovering delicious flavors that spark your interest can improve the whole magic mushroom experience.
Transparency in Sourcing Look out for companies that place a high value on transparency in their production and sourcing procedures.
Peace of mind and quality assurance can be obtained by being aware of the origins of the mushrooms and the manufacturing process.
Customer Feedback and Reputation Prioritize brands with positive customer feedback and a strong reputation in the market.
Real user experiences can offer valuable insights into the effectiveness and overall satisfaction with the magic mushroom product you are interested in.
Budget Considerations Consider your budget when selecting a mushroom gummy. While quality is important, finding a product that aligns with your budget ensures a sustainable and enjoyable experience.
>>Check the best price for Amanita Mushroom Chocolate Caps at Utoya
How We Created the List of Best Mushroom Gummies Next, we discuss the main factors we have considered for our list of the best mushroom complex gummies.
Effectiveness Effectiveness was a top priority in our selection process. We looked for mushroom gummies that have been shown to provide health benefits and support overall well-being .
Types of Mushrooms The types of mushrooms used in the gummies were also a crucial consideration.
We sought out products that incorporated a variety of beneficial mushrooms , each with unique properties and potential health advantages.
Flavor Another significant component of our raking assessment was flavor.
We searched for mushroom complex gummies that would appeal to a broad spectrum of customers by providing tasty and palatable flavors.
Extraction Type We also closely examined the kind of extraction that was employed to make the gummies.
To preserve the health-promoting properties of the mushrooms, we looked for products that made use of premium extraction techniques.
FAQs For more valuable information on how to buy mushroom spores and mushroom extracts in the gummy form, check the section below.
Where to Buy Mushroom Gummies? Mushrooms-infused gummies are available from reputable retailers and online shops, such as Utoya , FOCL , and other companies featured here.
Who Shouldn‚Äôt Take Mushroom Gummies? Gummies with mushroom extracts should not be consumed by pregnant and nursing females, as well as people who take blood thinners, medications for diabetes and hypertension, and individuals with other medical conditions.
How Strong Are Mushroom Gummies? This depends on the type of mushroom extract used in gummies, but the market is loaded with quite potent options , including those products featured here.
Do Mushroom Gummies Help with Anxiety? Yes, mushroom gummies can help with anxiety. Even though there is evidence that some mushrooms may provide anti-anxiety properties, it is essential to see a healthcare provider for specific advice on managing anxiety.
Can Mushroom Gummies Make You Trip? It is unlikely that consuming mushrooms-infused gummies that have been prepared medicinally‚Äîas long as they are taken according to recommended dosage guidelines ‚Äîwill cause hallucinations.
However, it is crucial to use caution and follow the usage guidelines to avoid psychoactive effects.
Are Mushroom Gummies Safe to Take? Generally, mushroom-infused gummies are considered safe. Though to reduce the risk of side effects, it is crucial to remain responsible and exercise caution.
Are Mushroom Gummies Legal? The legal status of mushroom gummies varies by location and the specific mushrooms used in their production.
While these products are legal in some areas, in others, they are not, so understanding local laws is crucial.
What Is the Best Time of Day to Take Mushroom Gummies? The best time to eat mushrooms-infused gummies may vary depending on personal preferences and desired results.
While some prefer to consume them at nighttime, others take them sometime in the morning.
Best Mushroom Gummies ‚Äì The Takeaway With a wide array of mushroom gummies on the market, there is no wonder why many find it very challenging to find the right product, but we are here to help.
Whether you are looking for mushroom complex gummies to experience mood upliftment, greater energy, or stress relief, the selection of products featured here most certainly includes the right product based on your needs and preferences.
Infused with Lion‚Äôs Mane and other beneficial mushrooms, these products offer a wealth of potential health benefits , and this is especially true for our #1 pick, Amanita Mushroom Chocolate Caps by Utoya .
An equally delicious mushroom experience is to be expected with each other product on the list, so make sure you check them all once again.

author: Recorder Report
title: Shahnawaz Dahani rules out of Pak Shaheens‚Äô Darwin tour - Sports - Business Recorder
text: LAHORE: Fast bowler Shahnawaz Dahani has been ruled out of the Pakistan Shaheens‚Äô Darwin tour after picking up a back injury. Dahani will miss the second four-dayer against Bangladesh-A starting from Friday and the white-ball leg of the Darwin tour, which involves two one-day matches and the Top End T20 Series. The 25-year-old fast bowler, who picked up four wickets against Bangladesh-A in first four-day match, will return to Pakistan immediately and will be assessed by the medical panel before starting the rehabilitation process. Spin-bowling all-rounder Mubasir Khan has been added to the white ball squad as cover for Dahani. Khurram Shahzad, who was set to return after the completion of two four-day match series against Bangladesh-A, will now be available for selection in the two one-day matches against Northern Territory Strike and Bangladesh A on 4 and 6 August, respectively. The pacer Shahnawaz Dahani has been ruled out of the Pakistan Shaheens‚Äô Darwin tour after picking up a back injury. Dahani will miss the second four-dayer against Bangladesh A starting from Friday and the white-ball leg of the Darwin tour, which involves two one-day matches and the Top End T20 Series. The 25-year-old fast bowler, who picked up four wickets against Bangladesh A in first four-day match, will return to Pakistan immediately and will be assessed by the medical panel before starting the rehabilitation process. Spin-bowling all-rounder Mubasir Khan has been added to the white ball squad as cover for Dahani. Khurram Shahzad, who was set to return after the completion of two four-day match series against Bangladesh-A, will now be available for selection in the two one-day matches against Northern Territory Strike and Bangladesh-A on August 4 and 6, respectively. author: Katie Sergent | News Channel 3
title: chevron-right
text: WAKESHMA TOWNSHIP, Mich. ‚Äî An alleged West Michigan shooting has turned into a swatting investigation. Michigan State Police and Kalamazoo County deputies were called to Wakeshma Township at 11 a.m. Thursday after someone called about a shooting. That call, however, was found to be illegitimate, prompting authorities to investigate the alleged shooting as a "swatting call," according to state police on Twitter. Swatting, according to [Merriam Webster](https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/swat), means to make a fake report of an ongoing crime to "elicit a response from law enforcement (such as the dispatch of a SWAT unit)." "MSP would like to remind residents that these calls tie up valuable resources and are taken seriously," troopers said in a statement. "This case will be investigated to its fullest extent to identify & hold accountable those responsible for this incident." Anyone with information about this incident is asked to call Kalamazoo Silent Observer at 269-343-2100 or the Michigan State Police Paw Paw Post At 269-657-5551.

author: Rebecca Barnabi
title: Virginia awarded $17.5M for restoration projects on Assateague Island, in Isle of Wight County - Augusta Free Press
text: U.S. Sens. [Mark R. Warner](https://augustafreepress.com/?s=Mark+Warner) and [Tim Kaine](https://augustafreepress.com/?s=Tim+Kaine) of [Virginia](https://augustafreepress.com/?s=Virginia) announced $17.5 million in federal funding for restoration and resiliency projects that benefit coastal communities and tribes across the Commonwealth. The funding was awarded through the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration‚Äôs (NOAA) Transformational Habitat Restoration and Coastal Resilience grant program and made possible by the bipartisan infrastructure law and Inflation Reduction Act. ‚ÄúWe are fortunate to have such bountiful natural resources in Virginia, which is why we have championed efforts to protect and support Virginia‚Äôs great outdoors,‚Äù the senators said. ‚ÄúThis funding will help us continue combating climate change and preserve our beautiful.‚Äù The funding is broken down as follows: ¬∑Ducks Unlimited will receive $9.5 million in funding to restore Swan Cove, the southernmost impoundment at Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge on Assateague Island. ¬∑The Virginia Department of Wildlife Resources will receive $8 million in funding to protect eroding marshes at Ragged Island Wildlife Management Area in Isle of Wight County. NOAA Fisheries‚Äô announcement comes as a part of $286 million soon to be deployed across the nation to support critical ecosystems that will be affected by climate change and extreme weather over the coming decades. Warner and Kaine are strong advocates for Virginia‚Äôs environment. In May 2024, they announced another $14 million in funding for conservation projects across the Commonwealth.

author: Steven L. Taylor
title: Sunday‚Äôs Forum
text:
Im glad that the world has sorted itself out so well and we can spend a second day talking about the weather.
üòâ
+3deg f on the front porch this morning. +13deg f is the forecast high today in Makanda Township IL. One January morning in 1976 as I left for work at the Murphysboro IL Street Department about 10 miles from here the front porch thermometer showed -25deg f. Don‚Äôt mind if I never see that again.
Sometime in the recent past Dr. Joyner road tested a new format for OTB. It allowed contributors to embed cat videos with their comments. Too bad that didn‚Äôt work out.
The weather is another thing that we can‚Äôt do anything about, but have long accepted that we can‚Äôt. Lots of other stuff makes us angry and impotent, because we have no positive effect. Discussing the weather can be helpful.
For what‚Äôs it‚Äôs worth this morning, bright blue sky and low 30‚Äôs, that maybe the high for the week.
For those who live vicariously, our trip update:
Today is the day that we (the wife and I) had scheduled our departure from Pensacola for Evergreen CO via RV.
As we are both avid snowboarders, getting back to the Summit County and making some freeride turns is our driving motivation.
Whie google maps may say that is a 20-hour drive, in reality it is a 6-day drive of reasonable travel time and breaks, with overnight stays along the way.
‚ÄúReasonable‚Äù being a mapped 4.5 hour drive (which becomes 6 usually start to finish). We tried longer segments but running an RV for a 10 hour goal became stupidly exhausting, with nights being far too short to get rest.
Looking at the arctic blast, mapping out the weather for our route, it became obvious that leaving today would bring us into the potential of freezing rain in Jackson MS, northern LA and eastern TX. and continued bitter cold as we went westward.
By delaying departure until Wednesday, we may be leaving Pensacola on a chill morning (sub freezing low the night before in the gulf coast area), but with dramatically improved weather along the way, with highs in the 50‚Äôs and 60‚Äôs.
Our planned travel takes us from Pensacola through Mobile AL for our first night stay in Jackson MS. Then on through LA to Kilgore TX, on through Dallas (‚Ä¶uugh. worlds worst drivers) to Witchita Falls, TX, up through Amarillo TX to Dumas TX, then through northern NM and up and over the mountain via Raton Pass toward Trinidad, a stay in southern Colorado in Walsenburg, and then a short drive ‚Äúup the hill‚Äù to our home near Genesee / Mt. Vernon.
Last summer our drive to Colorado had us in Wichita Falls for the 114 degree heat wave. Outrageously miserable. Did not want to discover the other extreme of that spectrum.
While fuel costs are always higher than one would like (as one can imagine it would be, driving a small home down the road), lodging/parking costs are inexpensive. We are not the type that pull into a Walmart and crank up the generator, so we look for interesting and cheap stops along the way. State Parks are usually reasonable, but we were surprised how many communities provide a free/donation RV spot with power, water and centralized sanitary dump.
Leflur‚Äôs Bluff in Jackson and Lathrup State Park in Walsenburg CO fit in the first category, Kilgore, Wichita Falls and Dumas fit in the second.
Well‚Ä¶ calling Dumas ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù is really a stretch. Let‚Äôs just say cheap for that one and let it go at that.
Finally, no, I am NOT a person that considers himself a member of the RV culture or the ‚ÄúVan Life‚Äù smiling happy people youtube clique. This is just a way to connect two points for me.
I like traveling by air, in the front of the plane. Roughing it for me is room service. This RV thing is such an anomaly. But I refuse to pretend that a 125lb malamute is a ‚Äúservice animal‚Äù to get him on a plane, so there is no other real option.
I think the Leamonheads said it best:
The Outdoor Type
Keep warm folks!
Apparently Mark Twain never said:
‚ÄúThe coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco.‚Äù
@
liberal capitalist: Kevin Drum has a chart, butI repeat myself, showing that, inflation adjusted, gas is as cheap as it‚Äôs been in the last 20 years. Way to go Brandon.
I used to tow to races in an RV. Typically relatively short distances so I wasn‚Äôt that upset about fuel cost.But it was a nuisance that gas for a while was over $5 and I couldn‚Äôt fill the tank because of the $75 dollar limit on credit card transactions at the dispenser.
The one day game I attended at the stick back in the‚Äô80s was at least that bad but Giants came from behind to beat the Mets in xtra innings so it was good times.
(No runner on 2nd base to start the 10th inning. That rule makes me want to puke.)
@
Bill Jempty: Laura Loomer, ‚Äúa far-right Florida (of course) activist and former congressional candidate‚Äù charged that Nikki Haley‚Äôs defense contractor donors arranged the bad weather for the Iowa caucus.
The other day, during one of The Bulwark‚Äôs podcasts, Ben Wittes recommended Ionescu‚Äôs Rhinoceros as an absurdist political allegory, with a lot of relevance for our time. After reading it yesterday, boy howdy, is he right. While people keep turning into rhinoceroses, other people just dither, worrying about the wrong things. There are definite connections with today‚Äôs dithering, such as the endless articles about what Trump voters really want, the ridiculous pretense of life going on as normal (hence the obsessive media focus on the meaningless Republican debates), and the hesitations in calling things what they really are. It‚Äôs a short read, and worth it.
@
https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861046: South edge of Sarasota county here. Howdy.
More of the intersection between literature and our current unpleasantness:
I‚Äôm re-reading Beowulf. While Googling for answers to questions I had about some odd elements of the story I had forgotten (swimming in armor?!?), I found a blog with the enticing title, Better Living Through Beowulf. One of the featured posts,
‚ÄúHow Beowulf Can Save America,‚Äù an excerpt from the author‚Äôs book, is definitely worth reading. It describes Beowulf as a parable about anger, and how it can turn us into monsters.
In America today we do not face threats of death and enslavement. We do, however, face a roiling anger that is undermining our governing institutions, setting citizen against citizen, and preventing collective problem-solving. In its account of Beowulf battling and defeating the three monsters, the epic captures our own situation and shows us how to deal with it.
We‚Äôre an angry country. The traditional liberal view of politics has been, ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs identify the sources of the anger, and deal with it. Then the anger will go away.‚Äù However, that perspective overlooks that the problem may also be the anger itself. People can get drunk on anger, especially given the ease with which they can justify their anger as righteous. Whether it‚Äôs Anglo-Saxons revenging themselves on their neighbors for stolen livestock, or a segment of white Americans outraged that their Mayberry vision of the United States doesn‚Äôt exist, people can quickly turn into angerholics.
Generative AI is going to kill Google. I‚Äôm setting up a specific brand of Network Attached Storage on my home network and wanted to see if I could use it as a drive for Time Capsule. I googled ‚ÄúHow do I use a Buffalo NAS as a Time Capsule drive‚Äù and saw that the first thing that popped up was from a user who did specifically that thing. Oh Joy! ‚Ä¶ and then realized that it was just generative AI bullshit and didn‚Äôt offer any real help at all. Then I scanned down the next 7-8 Google hits. Yep, same kind of bullshit. At least the awkward language, the bizarre emphasis on irrelevant details, and the logorrhea tips you off. But as it gets ‚Äúbetter‚Äù that tip off will go away. It will still provide bullshit though.
One of the most amazing and useful things about the internet: searching for a somewhat unusual use case and finding someone who has done that very thing. And now it‚Äôs gone, almost overnight. I don‚Äôt know that we‚Äôll ever be able to use it that way again.
@
Kingdaddy: Serendipitously, Kevin Drum hits the same theme today. He starts by quoting a Peggy Noonan column on the danger Trump supporters see in our modern world. Then quotes a similar column of hers from the 70s. Drum concludes,
We all live in the richest country in the richest era of history. We‚Äôre mostly well paid, well fed, and get good medical care. We have so many entertainment options we barely know how to handle them. If we‚Äôd all just buck up and stop being scared of the monsters under our beds, maybe we‚Äôd finally figure out just how much of life there is to enjoy.
Maybe the lesson is that we shouldn‚Äôt be sending out Cletus safaris to find the causes of their discontent so we can address them. Maybe it‚Äôs like stochastic terrorism. Maybe the problem is that the potential for Trumpian faux populism is always there, under the surface, available for amoral politicians, Huey Long, Hitler, Orban, etc., to summon it up. More of a psychological than political leaning. Maybe the actionable problem is the amoral politicians.
We could, as one example, reform our candidate selection process so it doesn‚Äôt promote opportunistic extremists. Or enforce the clear Constitutional prohibition against someone holding an office who has previously violated an oath of office by attempting to overthrow the government
I had not really been following the Bill Ackman stuff that closely. I had thought his wife‚Äôs plagiarism was limited to some footnote and quotation errors. Turns out she copied entire paragraphs. Not surprisingly, the guy thinks it‚Äôs OK when it was his wife. My bet at the time with Gay, and it still remains, is that low level plagiarism is actually very common. People consciously or not writing almost word for word what they read elsewhere. I think when you are writing technical stuff and someone else has worded something well it just sticks with you.
However, it turns out the guy is a whackadoodle in a number of areas. Including supporting Sam Bankman-Fried up until he was convicted, supporter of RFK as an anti-vaxxer and Kyle Rittenhouse was a patriot.
https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2024/01/bill-ackman-neri-oxman-plagiarism-wikipedia-insider-harvard-mit.html
Steve
@
https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861047: ‚ÄúIonescu‚Äôs Rhinoceros as an absurdist political allegory‚Äù
There was also a film version made for the short-lived American Film Theater in 1974, starring Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder. You can rend it on Amazon‚Ä¶
@
MarkedMan: Yesterday I was just trying to ask Google about a map of the Dakar Rally, because I was made aware that it no longer went to Dakar, Senegal. Google provided completely baffling results which were useless, for example telling me about some street market in Dakar. This shit used to work.
After asking seven different ways, I finally just went to Wikipedia and discovered it moved to South America at one point due to unrest in Mauritania, then eventually to Saudi Arabia. It turns out it was the history that I was curious about, which would have normally come up in the first page or two of Google results. Now they apparently decide what they think you‚Äôre asking, usually incorrectly, and then only give you an answer for that wrong question.
@
Kingdaddy: I read the Seamus Heaney translation a few years ago when it came out. It was so much more enjoyable than when it was forced upon me in school. Hope you enjoy it.
I‚Äôm re-reading Beowulf.
Hw√¶t!?
Oh Joy! ‚Ä¶ and then realized that it was just generative AI bullshit and didn‚Äôt offer any real help at all. Then I scanned down the next 7-8 Google hits. Yep, same kind of bullshit.
I keep waiting for Google to offer a feedback mechanism on search results that allows you to flag crap, presumably with a captcha-equivalent test for being an actual person. Surely that information would be extremely useful to them, and users would be happy to provide it‚Ä¶
@
Franklin: I commented above about Laura Loomer‚Äôs craziness @ gVOR10:. I couldn‚Äôt remember which female RW loon has said it. Try writing a Google search string today ‚ÄúXYZ Iowa caucus‚Äù that doesn‚Äôt return a huge list of standard issue ‚ÄúIowa caucus‚Äù less XYZ. Their algorithms seem to hugely prioritize popularity over content.
@
Franklin:
Now they apparently decide what they think you‚Äôre asking
Unfortunately I suspect it‚Äôs worse than that. I don‚Äôt think those are Google answers for the most part. It‚Äôs dozens of people trying to monetize AI.
@
https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861066:
Maybe the problem is that the potential for Trumpian faux populism is always there, under the surface, available for amoral politicians, Huey Long, Hitler, Orban, etc., to summon it up. More of a psychological than political leaning.
This.
Of course, this has been true all along of conservatism, as well. There are no conservative policies ‚Äî the same policy can be conservative or anti-conservative, depending on when and where you propose it. Republicanism was radically anti-conservative 300 years ago, and is conservative now. Evangelical Christianity was radically anti-conservative 200 years ago, and still is in the UK, but is conservative here. Gun control is deeply conservative in the UK and deeply anti-conservative in the US. Ditto national health care, national educational standards, etc. When it isn‚Äôt a fig leaf for raw greed, conservatism is a psychological phenomenon tied to asymmetric risk aversion. The least comprehensible argument of all to a conservative is ‚Äúwhat have we got to lose?‚Äù.
Apparently Mark Twain never said:
‚ÄúThe coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco.‚Äù
The inverse of that is beautiful January days like today, blue skies, crisp air & mid-high 50s. I‚Äôm in the East Bay, but SF is about the same today. It‚Äôs probably a fantastic day to drive up the coast, but I‚Äôve got work to do.
@
https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861036:
‚Ä¶ showing that, inflation adjusted, gas is as cheap as it‚Äôs been in the last 20 years.
Oh, this I know. But it‚Äôs still $800 ‚Äì $1000 to do that 1500 mile trip.
I justify it in my head, thinking that it is in the realm of possibility that two airline tickets + massive dog crate could also cost me approximately the same to do that trip.
However, as a former Chevy Bolt owner that had (what felt like) free power for 4 years, seeking out that cheap pump sucks.
@
steve:
My bet at the time with Gay, and it still remains, is that low level plagiarism is actually very common. People consciously or not writing almost word for word what they read elsewhere. I think when you are writing technical stuff and someone else has worded something well it just sticks with you.
One of the textbooks that I used in the writing from sources class (Eng. 102 at my schools) that I taught from suggested that source material always be copied word-for-word from the source for research notes.* The reason to copy exactly was that as the writer revises their draft, their paraphrases will move back toward the original source material so writers need exact copies of their source material‚Äôs paraphrased content to check against.
(Of course, given that Ackman is an enemy, and a political one at that, this information should not be used in an attempt to somehow imagine any excuse or explanation of what happened. Oxman‚Äôs actions cannot possibly be anything other than nefarious. üòê )
*Until I used the specific text this suggestion had come from, I don‚Äôt recall ever having heard this suggestion before‚Äìeven though I had taken a year-long research workshop while I was writing the thesis for my degree in music history. Then again, universities only taught composition to ‚Äúremedial‚Äù students in those days. The rest of us learned how to write before we got to college and didn‚Äôt need any instruction.
Here‚Äôs a good explanation of the MAX 9 door plug‚Äôs workings, and informed speculation on how the incident may have happened.

https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861095: Amazon has 3rd party people (or non-people algorithms) using AI to generate product descriptions, sometimes resulting in error messages as product names. https://futurism.com/amazon-products-ai-generated
Our dystopian present is not what we imagined it would be 20 years ago when it was our dystopian future.
(I was predicting e-ink tattoos that show ads until you pay them off. It can still happen, but now I expect it to be a subscription you need to pay for the rest of your life, until the managing company stops supporting it and you have error messages. Also it would be a target for hackers and ransomware)
I grew up in Chicago, which is fairly cold and windy and then spent ten years in Rochester, NY, which is even more cold and windy. Now I live in Maryland where grown-ass people huddle inside on any day lower than 50 and whine about the cold like little babies. I was just out for a walk along the Inner Harbor and I had a revelation: they literally don‚Äôt know how to dress themselves. It was cold, but not super cold, maybe 36, but windy as hell. Had to walk backwards through a couple of spots where a some buildings pinched off a wind tunnel. I saw all these people wearing what looked like serious coats but in a worse than useless way. Loose at the bottom and not zipped all the way up, so as to leave plenty of room around the neck. In other words, their coat was a chimney, guaranteed to suck all the heat out. And not one in ten had their damn hood up, the thing specifically designed to block the wind. I was out for an hour and a half with a proper coat, hat and gloves and hiking half boots with a decent sole. My only concern with heat was when I got away from the water and into a neighborhood which blocked the wind a bit so I had to readjust zippers and such to keep from getting overheated.
I have a friend who was the victim of a violent crime about a week ago, and a third friend and I were helping them around yesterday to be supportive and help keep them calm. Unfortunately, they had something of a breakdown in a train station. While we were trying to comfort them, this lady kind of sidled up and had the unmitigated gall to try and use that moment as a hook to proselytize to them, and what the ever loving fuck is wrong with people these days.
@
Kathy: That was good. Thanks
I know there are a few people here who follow Libertarian sites and I was wondering how they are treating their boy, Milei, in Argentina, given that he‚Äôs going all in shifting that country to Libertarian principles. Are they ignoring him? Embracing him? Predicting that Argentina will shortly rule the world?
@
Stormy Dragon: When I worked on campaigns ages ago, I was onsite in district for a special election and was in a car accident. The candidate‚Äôs wife tried that crap with me maybe an hour after my car got towed away, asking me if I had died in the wreck, would I have been saved.
Let‚Äôs just say that incident didn‚Äôt endear me to religion, particularly that flavor of proselytizing. I really have a BIG BIG problem with people who cannot keep that stuff to themselves. Read the room, lady.
@
Jen:

Mentour

(Probably just some guys slightly odd family name and he‚Äôs sick of the jokes, but he‚Äôs not here, is he?)

https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861121: Marginal Revolution mentions Milei. Not a lot about him, but a point of interest. And his success seems to be assumed. The attitude seems to be that Libertarianism cannot fail, it can only be failed.

Doug Burgum endorsed Trump for president. Apparently when Obama he disrespected all the heartland states, and trying to work with his administration was a disaster. Maybe it was like Cleavon Litle in Blazing Saddles. he couldn‚Äôt get past the color of his skin. Guys like Burgum truly have no integrity.

On another note, decent chance that this kills any hope for Arthur Blank to get Belichick to Atlanta. I doubt McCarthy survives this.
A couple weeks ago, I commented to someone that I couldn‚Äôt see Belichick tolerating Jones and Son. But since then, I‚Äôve read some seemingly solid reporting that there is mutual admiration between Jerry and BB. If that‚Äôs the case, that seems to be a likely destination for the sith lord.
@
Kathy:
Just to add: The reports of loose bolts apply to the two that hold the lower brackets to the plane, not the retaining pins, and are visible on the shot at 16:30. Like he said all reports in the press are questionable though.
I‚Äôm curious about that myself. I may take a look at some point soon.
I know one thing, if I see a description of a person that includes something to the effect a economist of the Austrian School, I feel pretty comfortable dismissing that person.
But that dismissal is a little harder to do when that person is influential in some way, and impossible if that person is a head of state.

https://www.outsidethebeltway.com#comment-2861145: Here is my prediction. Absolute failure, at which point Libertarians will memory hole him and never mention him again. They will not think about the failure or learn from it in any way.
Remember Sam Brownback? Savior of Kansas? The one who would finally show the world and all the haters the unbelievable success a libertarian government would bring? Well, if you remember him you must not be a libertarian, because they certainly don‚Äôt.
[I had to look him up. He resigned as governor in 2018 to become Trump‚Äôs Ambassador at Large for International Religious Freedom, whatever that was]

SenyorDave: I think we have new candidate for Chief Sycophant aka VP in the running.
Predictable play: a nobody candidate drops out, throws support to the frontrunner in the hopes he will get picked for the term in which the hamberders catch up with him.
The Detroit Lions just won a playoff game, their first playoff victory since defeating the Dallas Cowboys on January 5, 1992.
Next Sunday they‚Äôll meet‚Ä¶either the Eagles or the Buccaneers, it‚Äôs not decided yet. But they‚Äôll play at home again thanks to Dallas‚Äô loss today.

author: Sarah Hawley
title: 'One-of-a-kind' girl born with heart outside chest has pioneering surgery
text:
Vanellope, now seven, undergoes more surgery to reconstruct a "cage" around her heart, using her ribs. 'One-of-a-kind' girl born with heart outside chest has pioneering surgery
23 hours ago Share Save Sarah Hawley BBC News, East Midlands Share Save
Supplied Vanellope Hope Wilkins, now aged seven, was born with her heart outside of her body
Vanellope Hope Wilkins made medical history when she was born with her heart outside of her body in 2017. Described by experts as "one of a kind", Vanellope had three operations to place her heart back in her chest due to an extremely rare condition called ectopia cordis. The hospital where she was born - Glenfield Hospital in Leicester - says it knows of no other case in the UK where the baby has survived. Now seven years old, Vanellope has undergone groundbreaking surgery to reconstruct a protective cage around her heart - using her ribs.
The BBC was given exclusive access into theatre, when the operation took place at the East Midlands Congenital Heart Centre, based at the Leicester Royal Infirmary, last Wednesday. Warning: This story contains an image of surgery
Glenfield Hospital A team of around 50 staff worked to bring Vanellope into the world, on 22 November 2017
It's early morning outside theatre, and a team of specialist medical experts gather for a briefing to discuss the unprecedented surgery about to take place. Vanellope still has no breastbone, leaving her heart covered by just by a thin layer of skin. Surgeons have come up with a plan to use her ribs to form a protective cage inside her chest. Consultant paediatric surgeon Nitin Patwardhan was one of the 50-strong medical team at Vanellope's birth on 22 November. Now he is set to play a leading role again in surgery, which has never been performed like this before. "I'd lie if I say I don't get nervous," he says. "But having been in this profession for so many years, you actually look forward to it because at the end of the day, you're doing something that will change somebody's life." He remembers how "everything was unknown" when Vanellope was born,‚Ä¶
Sarah Hawley

author: Nicholas, Linda M.
title: Domestic Multicrafting for Exchange at Prehispanic Ejutla, Oaxaca, Mexico
text:
Share the story of what Open Access means to you
University of Michigan needs your feedback to better understand how readers are using openly available ebooks. You can help by taking a short, privacy-friendly survey.
Domestic Multicrafting for Exchange at Prehispanic Ejutla, Oaxaca, Mexico
Gary M. Feinman and Linda M. Nicholas
Open Access
This is an open access title available under the terms of a CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 License. It is free to read, download and share on the BAR Digital platform. Archaeological investigations at the prehispanic Ejutla site in Oaxaca, Mexico, have had a foundational role in reframing our perspectives on Mesoamerican economies, specifically craft specialization. This volume reports on the excavations of a residential complex located at the southern limits of the Valley of Oaxaca system, where evidence was recovered for multiple craft activities associated with a single non-elite domestic unit. The residential occupants crafted a variety of ornaments from marine shell, mostly sourced to the Pacific Coast, but few were consumed by the householders themselves. In addition, the Ejutla craftworkers produced a range of ceramic utilitarian vessels, including domestic wares and figurines, as well as small lapidary objects. Many of the craft goods produced were destined for exchange, circulating in both local and longer-distance networks. The findings have laid a basis for new theorizing on prehispanic economic production and the revision of prior notions that presumed principally local economies, in which specialized production for exchange was centered in nondomestic workshops.
Citable Link
Published: 2024
Publisher: BAR Publishing
- 9781407361703 (ebook)
- 9781407361697 (paper)
BAR Number: S3177

author: Keeley Milne
title: Record-destroying ultrarunner David Roche hopes to win Western States 100
text:
Home > Trail Running Record-destroying ultrarunner David Roche hopes to win Western States 100 "I'm in it to win it," Roche says about the iconic 100-miler Photo by: Cody Bare @codybare_ Colorado‚Äôs David Roche isn‚Äôt just training for Western States 100 (WSER)‚Äîhe may be redefining what‚Äôs possible. A coach, writer and ultrarunning phenom, Roche made waves when he shattered the Leadville 100 course record, a performance so dominant it was chosen as Trail Performance of the Year. Now, he‚Äôs offering a behind-the-scenes journey as he chases a bold goal: to stand on top of the podium at WSER.
‚ÄúI‚Äôm in it to win it‚Äù Roche likens his journey to WSER as more than a training plan‚Äîit‚Äôs also a science experiment with his own body as the subject. In the intro to his series, he reflected on his 18 years of endurance training, likening each day to laying a brick in a structure he couldn‚Äôt yet envision. ‚ÄúNow, I get 166 more opportunities to lay down bricks to the dream I never really let myself fully imagine,‚Äù he said.
But Roche is doing more than dreaming‚Äîhe‚Äôs determined to chase that first-place finish.‚ÄúI know it probably ruffles some feathers when I say that I‚Äôm in it to win it. I‚Äôm not that guy, right? Deep down, I definitely don‚Äôt think I am. Well‚Ä¶ I was wrong both times before.‚Äù
19-year-old Leadville 100 course record falls
Redefining the playbook To make history, Roche knows he can‚Äôt play by the usual ultrarunning rules. His plan? Show up with ‚Äútrack-ready 5K fitness‚Äù to outpace even the best in the sport. He‚Äôs throwing himself into speedwork and running economy like never before, aiming to push boundaries and rewrite the expectations of a 100-mile race. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to get fast. Really fast,‚Äù he says.
David Roche Javelina Jundred 2024. Photo: Cody Bare @codybare_ Why you‚Äôll want to watch Roche is inviting the world to follow his journey in a new YouTube series, Road to Western States, with the first episode titled ‚ÄúShock the World.‚Äù Roche offers a raw, unfiltered look at what it takes to chase greatness. From speed workouts to GI training, mental challenges , fueling and more, Roche‚Äôs videos offer a front-row seat to an athlete willing to risk it all for a shot at making history.
‚ÄúMaybe it will work. Maybe I‚Äôll crash and burn,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúEither way, I‚Äôll have a story to tell.‚Äù For anyone who‚Äôs ever dreamed big or rooted for the underdog, this is the story to watch. Check out Episode 1 of Road to Western States here , directed by Cody Bare , and prepare to be inspired.
Check out the latest buyer's guide: The one running jacket you need this winter This winter running jacket from Craft might be your smartest purchase this season
